answer_html: The first gives the solution \(\displaystyle x = e\) and the second gives \(\displaystyle x = e^{-1}\) both seen by exponentiating both sides.Both of these values are in the domain of the original function and so this completes the proof.
answer_latex:
The first gives the solution
$\displaystyle x = e$ and the second gives $\displaystyle x = e^{-1}$
both seen by exponentiating both sides.Both of these values are in the
domain of the original function and so this completes the proof.
hints_html: Remember that tangent line slopes are just derivatives at points. So take derivatives and set them equal.
hints_latex:
Remember that tangent line slopes are just derivatives at points. So
take derivatives and set them equal.
hints_raw: Remember that tangent line slopes are just derivatives at points. So take derivatives and set them equal.
sols_html:
First, we take derivatives and see that

\(\displaystyle f'(x) = \frac{1}{x^{3}}(3x^{2}) = \frac{3}{x}\)

\(\displaystyle g'(x) = 3(\ln(x))^{2}\frac{1}{x} = \frac{3(\ln(x))^{2}}{x}\)

Setting the derivatives equal to each other gives

\(\displaystyle \frac{3}{x} = \frac{3(\ln(x))^{2}}{x}\)

which implies that

\(\displaystyle (\ln(x))^{2} = 1\)

Hence, we have that \(\displaystyle \ln(x) = 1\) or \(\displaystyle \ln(x) = -1\). The first gives the solution \(\displaystyle x = e\) and the second gives \(\displaystyle x = e^{-1}\) both seen by exponentiating both sides. Both of these values are in the domain of the original function and so this completes the proof.
sols_latex:
First, we take derivatives and see that

$\displaystyle f'(x) = \frac{1}{x^{3}}(3x^{2}) = \frac{3}{x}$

$\displaystyle g'(x) = 3(\ln(x))^{2}\frac{1}{x} = \frac{3(\ln(x))^{2}}{x}$

Setting the derivatives equal to each other gives

$\displaystyle \frac{3}{x} = \frac{3(\ln(x))^{2}}{x}$

which implies that

$\displaystyle (\ln(x))^{2} = 1$

Hence, we have that $\displaystyle \ln(x) = 1$ or
$\displaystyle \ln(x) = -1$. The first gives the solution
$\displaystyle x = e$ and the second gives $\displaystyle x = e^{-1}$
both seen by exponentiating both sides. Both of these values are in the
domain of the original function and so this completes the proof.
sols_raw:
First, we take derivatives and see that

<math> \displaystyle f'(x) = \frac{1}{x^{3}}(3x^{2}) = \frac{3}{x} </math>

<math> \displaystyle g'(x) = 3(\ln(x))^{2}\frac{1}{x} = \frac{3(\ln(x))^{2}}{x}</math>

Setting the derivatives equal to each other gives

<math> \displaystyle \frac{3}{x} = \frac{3(\ln(x))^{2}}{x}</math>

which implies that

<math> \displaystyle (\ln(x))^{2} = 1</math>

Hence, we have that <math> \displaystyle \ln(x) = 1</math> or <math> \displaystyle \ln(x) = -1 </math>. The first gives the solution <math> \displaystyle x = e</math> and the second gives <math> \displaystyle x = e^{-1}</math> both seen by exponentiating both sides. Both of these values are in the domain of the original function and so this completes the proof.
statement_html: Let \(f(x) = \ln(x^{3})\) and \(g(x) = (\ln x)^{3}\). Find all values of x where the tangent lines of these two functions have the same slope (or show that no such values exist).
statement_latex:
Let $f(x) = \ln(x^{3})$ and $g(x) = (\ln x)^{3}$. Find \emph{all} values
of \emph{x} where the tangent lines of these two functions have the same
slope (or show that no such values exist).
statement_raw: Let <math>f(x) = \ln(x^{3})</math> and <math>g(x) = (\ln x)^{3}</math>. Find ''all'' values of ''x'' where the tangent lines of these two functions have the same slope (or show that no such values exist).
